G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under the common and statutory law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment).

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell Division of the District Court Department because the leased premises are located at 81 Maple Street, Lowell, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201321.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell Division of the District Court Department because the leased premises are located at 81 Maple Street, Lowell, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including 10.proposition: The State Sanitary Code requires that dwelling units be kept in a condition that is safe, clean, and sanitary, and free from conditions which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants, including chronic dampness and mold-like conditions.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that materially affect the health, safety, or comfort of the tenant, even where the landlord’s interference is the result of neglect or inaction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where serious interferences with tenants’ use—here, loud bar noise preventing sleep and making apartments not reasonably habitable—are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, even absent intent to evict. The opinion rejects any strict nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction and focuses on the landlord’s control and failure to abate the condition, thus squarely supporting that quiet enjoyment protects against substantial interferences arising from the landlord’s neglect or inaction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that materially affect the health, safety, or comfort of the tenant, even where the landlord’s interference is the result of neglect or inaction.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains that “quiet enjoyment” means freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy and ties that concept both to common‑law doctrine and to statutory G.L. c. 186, § 14. It further holds that liability for interference with quiet enjoyment does not require malicious intent and may be based on the landlord’s reckless omission to act where unsanitary flooding conditions interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, thus covering serious conditions affecting health, safety, or comfort even when arising from neglect or inaction.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…. When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that materially affect the health, safety, or comfort of the tenant, even where the landlord’s interference is the result of neglect or inaction.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and reaffirms that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment can be based on negligent omissions, such as failing to repair known defects, and is not limited to intentional conduct. That aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects tenants against serious interferences—including conditions affecting health, safety, or comfort—caused by a landlord’s neglect or inaction. The decision’s focus is on the fault standard (requiring at least negligence and notice), not on redefining the scope of what kinds of interferences qualify, so the support is indirect but consistent.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises… we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless… and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14… a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”}

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that materially affect the health, safety, or comfort of the tenant, even where the landlord’s interference is the result of neglect or inaction.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 as protecting tenants from serious interferences with tenancy and focuses on the landlord’s conduct, including what the landlord “failed to do” or “permitted to be done.” It holds that a landlord may be liable where, through inaction in the face of known criminal activity in common areas, it permits a condition that seriously interferes with tenants’ use and enjoyment, even though the landlord is not itself committing the wrongful acts. This squarely supports the proposition that serious interferences—including conditions affecting health, safety, or comfort—can breach quiet enjoyment even when arising from landlord neglect or inaction.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that materially affect the health, safety, or comfort of the tenant, even where the landlord’s interference is the result of neglect or inaction.
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.support_reasoning: The court accepts, without challenge from the landlord, the Housing Court judge’s conclusion that the unrepaired roof leaks constituted both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The defects were ongoing physical conditions (water leaks causing accumulation in the living room and a closet), not intentional acts, indicating that serious, health- and comfort-impacting conditions created by the landlord’s failure to repair can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, the opinion does not extensively analyze the doctrinal scope of the covenant, so the support is implicit rather than fully articulated.
Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.... It is clear that the plaintiff’s actual damages exceeded three times her monthly rent of $47. Her actual damages included the diminution of the value of the leasehold due to the breach of the implied warranty of habitability, as well as the damage to her personal property."

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: Conditions that pose threats to a tenant’s health or safety can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations, leaks, cockroaches, and an insecure door, and affirms damages under G.L. c. 93A, negligence, implied warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 (which concerns quiet enjoyment). However, the excerpt does not analyze or state that health- or safety-threatening conditions constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment; it treats these conditions primarily as habitability and 93A issues. Any connection to interference with quiet enjoyment is implicit and not expressly articulated as a legal rule in this text.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt:
The judge found that at the inception of LeClairs tenancy there were a number of violations of the State Sanitary Code and that these problems had caused the prior tenant to vacate the premises after living there a few months. He also found that the landlord was repeatedly notified of the ongoing leaks and other problems on several occasions, and that, despite these complaints, the leakage and the roach problem remained uncorrected through April, 1982.
...
On October 23, 1981, LeClair sent Brown a demand letter seeking damages and requesting relief (repairs) under c. 93A for problems relating to leaks, the January 31, 1980, flood, cockroaches, the assault, and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Miller v. Prescott, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 31.raw_text: Miller v. Prescott, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 312 (1999)
Miller v. Prescott, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 31.proposition: Conditions that pose threats to a tenant’s health or safety can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Miller v. Prescott, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 31.support_reasoning: The case concerns a legal malpractice claim arising from criminal representation and the preclusive effect of an undisturbed guilty plea on a subsequent malpractice action. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or conditions affecting a tenant’s health or safety. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that health or safety threats can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Miller v. Prescott, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 31.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt. The opinion addresses criminal malpractice, guilty pleas, and preclusion doctrines, not landlord-tenant quiet enjoyment or health/safety conditions.]

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: A landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for failing to take reasonable steps to correct conditions within the landlord’s control that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 generally, but it does not articulate or apply a standard that a landlord is liable for failing to take reasonable steps to correct conditions within the landlord’s control that materially impair the character and value of the premises. Instead, it concludes there was no interference with quiet enjoyment because the landlord promptly repaired the cited defects. The case therefore does not serve as authority for the affirmative liability standard stated in the proposition.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is distinct from, but consistent with, the landlord’s obligations regarding habitability and compliance with the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The concurring/dissenting opinion expressly distinguishes between two concepts: (1) a broad, judicially created implied warranty of habitability/fitness that may go beyond the Code; and (2) an implied obligation, grounded in statutes and the State Sanitary Code, that premises meet minimum legal standards. The author criticizes the majority for suggesting that the new implied warranty of habitability "does not necessarily coincide with the Code’s requirements," thereby recognizing that the covenant/warranty concept is distinct from, though related to, statutory Code-compliance obligations. This directly reflects that quiet enjoyment/habitability doctrines can be separate from, but consistent with, sanitary code duties.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: Since it is clear that mandatory minimum standards for housing units as prescribed by statutes, ordinances, rules, regulations or codes having the force and effect of law cannot be waived or otherwise undercut by agreement of the parties to a tenancy, it appears that the opinion contemplates that the new implied warranty may require even higher standards to satisfy its requirement of fitness “for human occupation.” Thus these identical words would have one meaning under applicable statutes, ordinances, rules, regulations or codes, and they might have a different meaning under the proposed implied warranty. The court’s opinion itself says, in footnote 16, that “the protection afforded by the implied warranty of habitability does not necessarily coincide with the Code’s requirements.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The State Sanitary Code requires that dwelling units be kept in a condition that is safe, clean, and sanitary, and free from conditions which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants, including chronic dampness and mold-like conditions.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the State Sanitary Code primarily as the source of a landlord’s duty to maintain habitable premises and specifically mentions code provisions on heat and hot water. It does not state or interpret a general Sanitary Code requirement that dwelling units be safe, clean, and sanitary or free from conditions such as chronic dampness and mold-like conditions. The case is about loss of heat and hot water and rent abatement, not about dampness or mold, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code, adopted pursuant to authority granted in G. L. c. 111, § 5 (since amended, see G. L. c. 111, § 127A, for the current version), imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition, so the landlord could fairly expect and be expected to keep his rented premises habitable. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201).”

Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1.raw_text: Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1 (1992)
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1.proposition: When a landlord, after notice, fails to take reasonable steps to address an unhealthy or unsafe condition such as chronic mold growth interfering with the tenant’s use of essential areas (such as the bathroom), that failure can constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1.case_name: Catlin v. Board of Registration of Architects
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1 (1992), but an architect-licensing case involving John Catlin and the Board of Registration of Architects. It concerns statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 112, § 60G and related administrative and Commerce Clause issues, not landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or conditions such as mold in rental premises. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, the claimed proposition about a landlord’s failure to remedy unsafe conditions constituting substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. Boston Housing Auth., 414 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: The heart of this dispute is the proper interpretation of the word “prepared” in G. L. c. 112, § 60G (e). The statute authorizes the board to “revoke, suspend or annul the certificate of registration ... or otherwise discipline a registrant, upon proof satisfactory to the board ... (e) that the holder of such certificate of registration has permitted or suffered his official seal to be affixed to any plans, specifications or drawings not prepared by him or under his personal supervision by his regularly employed subordinates” (emphasis added).
